Bean was pursuing a music career when Motown asked him to record the song.
He says he had always known that he was gay, so it felt like a perfect fit.
I always say the lyric found me, and it was very natural.
Bean, now a retired pastor, was the founder of Unity Fellowship Church.
He ministered to gays and lesbians and was an activist during the AIDS crisis.
Bean says when he heard that Gaga was inspired by his recording, he was flattered.
I felt it was a great tribute, and it was the continuation of saving lives.
So you know, it has just been a blessing to my life.
And it's been a blessing, once again, to even another generation's life through the take that Gaga did on it.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""BORN THIS WAY"")

No matter...
As much as ""Born This Way"" has been embraced as a gay anthem, Tim Cox says it's also an anthem for anyone who feels outside the mainstream.
And he thinks it's the kind of anthem that has staying power.
You know, 50 years from now, when she's not singing anymore, I would not be surprised if the song that she's remembered for most is ""Born This Way.

This is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Farai Chideya.
On today's Roundtable, a slavery museum is asked to give back donations from a tobacco company, and illiteracy as a growing problem in the nation's capital.

Joining today's panel are political consultant Walter Fields, economist and author, Julianne Malveaux, the president and CEO of Last Word Productions Incorporated, and Ron Christie, VP of the lobbying Firm D.C.
Navigators and former special assistant to President George W.
Bush.
So welcome everybody and let's talk about smoking and how dollars flow into African-American organizations.
So an anti-smoking group wants the U.S.
National Slavery Museum to give back the money donated by tobacco powerhouse Phillip Morris.
The campaign for tobacco-free kids played on the relative nature of the museum by saying the tobacco company targets children for, quote, ""another form of slavery.
The president of the organization said the museum's association with the largest cigarette manufacturer in the U.S.
works against the museum's purpose.
Now, Julianne, there has been a lot of tobacco money flowing to African-American or African-American-themed organizations.
Number one, is this a fair demand, and number two, what about the language of the demand?
Well, Farai, I think I said a couple of weeks ago on this show that money and back are two words that an economist does not use in the same sentence.
No, they shouldn't give the money back.
Quite frankly, most cynically, I would see this as a form or reparation - slaves smoked.
The tobacco industry basically build it's back on the slave labor and on post-Reconstruction labor.
This is a modest investment in something that's important and national and no, I don't think it should be given back.
And I think that these folks have some issues in the way that they're dealing with black people, because part of the dialogue would be a dialogue about respect.
Illiteracy.
About a third of people living in the nation's capital are functionally illiterate compared to a fifth of the U.S.
population.
A fifth is pretty bad, a third is horrible.
Those numbers come from a report from the U.S.
Department of Education.
And their definition of someone who's functionally illiterate is somebody who has trouble doing things like understanding bus schedules, reading maps, filling out job applications.
McCain says the playhouse is a uniquely intimate venue and she wanted to show Richards what she's about to miss.
I had heard through the grapevine that possible closing and then she came to town and we wanted to at least be able to come and see it one more time.
(Soundbite of musical, ""Camelot"")
Unidentified Man #1: (Singing) Camelot, Camelot, I know it gives a person pause.
But in Camelot, Camelot, those are the legal laws...
It's ironically appropriate that the last show would be a musical about a mythical kingdom that began in great hope then crashed under the weight of ugly reality.
Earlier in the day, Sheldon Epps and Stephen Eich, the theater's artistic and executive directors, gave me a little history lesson as we sat in the playhouse's main auditorium.
Epps says there was also an acting school here in the early days.
The studios used to actually send people here to learn how to act and use their voices and all of that.
Eich and Epps roll out the many household names who worked on this stage.
Gene Hackman, Dustin Hoffman, Eve Arden, (unintelligible)...
Robert Preston, Robert Young, Sally Struthers - a lot of very, very well-known people.
The Spanish revival-style playhouse was built in 1924 and over the years has become a beloved community touchstone.
But the grim economy has crippled many of Pasadena's cultural institutions.
And now, the playhouse becomes yet another theater among many in the U.S.
that can't afford to remain open.
Epps says one of the scariest things about the playhouse's closure is what that says about the nation's overall cultural health.
If this can happen to this theater, to Pasadena Playhouse, then the arts in America are in big trouble.
(Soundbite of song, ""C'est Moi"")

So admir'bly fit.
A French Prometheus unbound.
Now, what the Pasadena Playhouse needs is a financial white knight, a Lancelot who can swiftly rise to its rescue.
Karen Grigsby Bates, NPR News.
